body.head.byline: By Clyde H. Farnsworth and Charlotte Evans

block.p: LEAD: American and Soviet academicians convened in Alexandria, Va., last week to discuss political and economic developments in Eastern Europe. The keynote speaker, Zbigniew Brzezinski, called it ''a reflection of what is taking place in the Soviet Union - glasnost.''

LEAD: American and Soviet academicians convened in Alexandria, Va., last week to discuss political and economic developments in Eastern Europe. The keynote speaker, Zbigniew Brzezinski, called it ''a reflection of what is taking place in the Soviet Union - glasnost.''

American and Soviet academicians convened in Alexandria, Va., last week to discuss political and economic developments in Eastern Europe. The keynote speaker, Zbigniew Brzezinski, called it ''a reflection of what is taking place in the Soviet Union - glasnost.''

The head of the Soviet delegation, Oleg Timofeyevich Bogomolov, was asked at a luncheon what he regarded as the major achievements of the three-day conference, which was sponsored by the International Research and Exchanges Board, a private group based in Princeton, N.J., that seeks to promote scholarly interaction with the Soviet Union.
Mr. Bogomolov seemed confused until the questioner made it clear he meant the Alexandria discussions.
''There is only one conference with a capital letter,'' Mr. Bogomolov said, referring to the recent Communist Party Conference in Moscow. The remark drew appreciative laughter from around the table.
